Narcissus: A practical clean-label backdoor attack with limited

pages 771‚Äì785, 2023.
references:
Over the past decades, deep learning has made significant advancements in various fields such as computer visionKrizhevsky et al. (2012); He et al. (2016), natural language processing Devlin et al. (2018), and gaming Silver et al. (2016, 2017). However, state-of-the-art machine learning (ML) models require a substantial amount of data to achieve strong performance Dosovitskiy et al. (2020); Tan and Le (2019). Unfortunately, in the current landscape of large models and extensive datasets, neural networks have been demonstrated to be vulnerable to attacks Goodfellow et al. (2014); Kurakin et al. (2016); Gu et al. (2017). Among them, backdoor attacks are the most covert and dangerous.

The classical backdoor attack BadNets, BlendGu et al. (2017); Chen et al. (2017) involves sticking a trigger to the source data and modifying its label to the target class. However, this type of attack is not very practical, as even basic data collectors could discern the correctness of labels.

To improve the success rate of backdoor attacks through human inspection, recent research has introduced the concept of clean-label backdoor attacks. One proposed baseline is optimizing triggers across different training dataset classes. The Label Consistency (LC) attack Turner et al. (2019) introduced two methods: one involves adding adversarial perturbations that make the original features more difficult to classify, and the other incorporates features from other non-target classes into target class samples through interpolation in the latent space of a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). The Hidden Trigger Backdoor Attack (HTBA) Saha et al. (2020) minimizes the distance in the feature space between perturbed inputs of the target class and inputs with triggers from non-target classes. However, they require access to the victim‚Äôs training dataset for all classes.

Other methods, aimed at further reducing reliance on the training dataset, NARCISSUS Zeng et al. (2023) introduced an efficient clean-label attack employing a dataset from the target class. By training a classifier capable of accurately categorizing public out-of-distribution (POOD) samples, then fine-tunes on the target class in the training set. Although this approach significantly decreases the need for extensive access to the training dataset, enhances the success rate of attacks, and reduces the poisoning rate, it still necessitates access to the training data.

Overall, the effectiveness of existing clean-label attacks largely relies on knowing training data from all classes or at least some portion of it. However, data originates from multiple independent sources in many real-world scenarios, making accessing the training data quite challenging. For instance, pre-trained models can be adapted to new tasks with only a small amount of training data. The typical approach for users is to download pre-trained deep models and acquire additional images from the internet to fine-tune the model for their specific task. In such applications, attackers cannot access or control users‚Äô training data. However, to the best of our knowledge, the existing clean-label backdoor attacks largely relies on an understanding of the entire training set or a portion of it.

To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to conduct clean-label attack without accessing the training set. In this paper, we propose ‚ÄôDFB‚Äô, a clean-label attack that requires no access to any training dataset and relies solely on knowledge of the target class. Leveraging Public Out-of-Distribution (POOD) samples, we use a decoder to accurately classify the target class against other classes. Subsequently, we generate a trigger that contains no features from the target class using an encoder. We find that this trigger effectively leads the victim network to associate the trigger with the target class. The distinction between our approach and existing methods is illustrated in Table 1.

Our contributions are as follows:

references: We compare our attack against existing clean-label attacks on the CIFAR10, Tiny-ImageNet, and TSRD datasets. Even at low poisoning rates of 0.1%, 0.025%, and 0.4%, respectively, DFB in the absence of training data achieves a significantly higher success rate than LC, HTBA, BadNets, and Blend, even when LC and HTBA access to the training set. The results as shown in Table 2.

Attack Effectiveness. Our comparative results with other attack methods are shown in Table 2. On CIFAR-10, Tiny-ImageNet, and TSRD datasets, with poisoning rates of 0.1%, 0.025%, and 0.4% respectively, DFB exhibits superior performance even under challenging conditions (i.e., without access to any training dataset). Utilizing fixed triggers from the POOD dataset, devoid of target-class features, and dynamically adjusting encoder triggers based on the training set, DFB achieves faster model injection. This results in a higher attack success rate (ASR) compared to LC and HTBA. In contrast to fair attacks like BadNets and Blend, our method shows higher success rates while preserving prediction accuracy on clean datasets. Further, in experiments attacking every class in CIFAR-10 and Tiny-ImageNet, given our restriction of no access to clean labels from the training set, our approach outperforms BadNet-c and Blend-c. We achieved the highest ASR on attacking all classes, where BadNet-c and Blend-c did not surpass a 10% ASR. Additionally, our performance exceeded that of HTBA, as depicted in Figure 3.

Trigger Evaluation. We conducted trigger evaluations on the CIFAR-10 and Tiny-ImageNet datasets. A clean ResNet network was trained, achieving test accuracies of 95.4% on CIFAR-10 and 69.3% on Tiny-ImageNet. We then applied various triggers to the entire training set and monitored their impact on CrossEntropyLoss, with results detailed in Table 4. Our findings indicate that triggers from BadNets and Blend were less effective in modifying image features, posing challenges for neural network learning. In contrast, DFB-generated triggers, optimized using the POOD dataset, significantly obscured key features, leading to a marked increase in CrossEntropyLoss. This effectively validates the approach outlined in our proposed formula 1.

Next, we will provide a detailed explanation of the DFB attack method. The overall architecture of the DFB is depicted in Figure 1.

Step 1: Training the POOD target class decoder and encoder. Initially, to meet the optimization goal in Formula 1, we collect the DP‚Å¢O‚Å¢O‚Å¢Dsubscriptùê∑ùëÉùëÇùëÇùê∑{D_{POOD}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P italic_O italic_O italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT dataset. A challenge arises because DP‚Å¢O‚Å¢O‚Å¢Dsubscriptùê∑ùëÉùëÇùëÇùê∑{D_{POOD}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P italic_O italic_O italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains multiple categories, making direct correlation with the formula‚Äôs components difficult. Thus, our first step is to transform DP‚Å¢O‚Å¢O‚Å¢Dsubscriptùê∑ùëÉùëÇùëÇùê∑{D_{POOD}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P italic_O italic_O italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into a binary classification dataset, DP‚Å¢O‚Å¢O‚Å¢DB‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚Å¢a‚Å¢r‚Å¢ysubscriptùê∑ùëÉùëÇùëÇsubscriptùê∑ùêµùëñùëõùëéùëüùë¶{D_{POOD_{B}inary}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P italic_O italic_O italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_n italic_a italic_r italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with labels comprising only the target class label p‚Å¢tùëùùë°ptitalic_p italic_t and a composite label p‚Å¢t¬Ø¬Øùëùùë°\overline{pt}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_p italic_t end_ARG for all non-target classes. This transformation enables the decoder to more effectively distinguish the target class features from others, unlike in a multi-class dataset. Therefore, we optimize the decoder by the following function:

Where p‚Å¢xùëùùë•pxitalic_p italic_x represents the data in the training dataset DP‚Å¢O‚Å¢O‚Å¢D‚Å¢_‚Å¢B‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚Å¢a‚Å¢r‚Å¢ysubscriptùê∑ùëÉùëÇùëÇùê∑_ùêµùëñùëõùëéùëüùë¶{D_{POOD\_Binary}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P italic_O italic_O italic_D _ italic_B italic_i italic_n italic_a italic_r italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and p‚Å¢yt‚Å¢r‚Å¢u‚Å¢eùëùsubscriptùë¶ùë°ùëüùë¢ùëí{py_{true}}italic_p italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_u italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT includes instances where either p‚Å¢tùëùùë°ptitalic_p italic_t or p‚Å¢t¬Ø¬Øùëùùë°\overline{pt}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_p italic_t end_ARG belongs to p‚Å¢yt‚Å¢r‚Å¢u‚Å¢eùëùsubscriptùë¶ùë°ùëüùë¢ùëí{py_{true}}italic_p italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_u italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
Step 2: Training the Encoder for Trigger Generation Without Target Class Features.
To optimize Œ¥ùõø\deltaitalic_Œ¥, we employ the encoder. Target class data p‚Å¢x*ùëùsuperscriptùë•p{x^{*}}italic_p italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is fed into the encoder to generate a corresponding residual Œ¥ùõø\deltaitalic_Œ¥. This Œ¥ùõø\deltaitalic_Œ¥ is then superimposed onto p‚Å¢x*ùëùsuperscriptùë•p{x^{*}}italic_p italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, creating p‚Å¢xfinish*ùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùë•finishpx_{\text{finish}}^{*}italic_p italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT finish end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Feeding p‚Å¢xfinish*ùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùë•finishpx_{\text{finish}}^{*}italic_p italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT finish end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into the decoder, we decode it to obtain its label. A loss function is constructed to refine Œ¥ùõø\deltaitalic_Œ¥, tackling the optimization issue outlined in Formula 1. Post-optimization, the encoder is deemed capable of producing a residual Œ¥*superscriptùõø{\delta^{*}}italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for images. When applied to the original image, this Œ¥*superscriptùõø{\delta^{*}}italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can strip the target image of any features of the current class.


Step 3: Trigger Selection and Injection. We propose two methods for trigger generation. The first method aims to identify triggers within the POOD dataset that maximize the likelihood of transforming the target image into a high-confidence non-target class using a specific loss function. The second method inputs xtrainsubscriptùë•trainx_{\text{train}}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT train end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the training set into the encoder to generate the corresponding Œ¥xtrainsubscriptùõøsubscriptùë•train\delta_{x_{\text{train}}}italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT train end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This Œ¥ùõø\deltaitalic_Œ¥ is then injected into the training set. The algorithms for generating Œ¥*superscriptùõø\delta^{*}italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT through these two trigger generation methods are detailed in Algorithm 1 and Algorithm 2, respectively.

Attack Effectiveness. Our comparative results with other attack methods are shown in Table 2. On CIFAR-10, Tiny-ImageNet, and TSRD datasets, with poisoning rates of 0.1%, 0.025%, and 0.4% respectively, DFB exhibits superior performance even under challenging conditions (i.e., without access to any training dataset). Utilizing fixed triggers from the POOD dataset, devoid of target-class features, and dynamically adjusting encoder triggers based on the training set, DFB achieves faster model injection. This results in a higher attack success rate (ASR) compared to LC and HTBA. In contrast to fair attacks like BadNets and Blend, our method shows higher success rates while preserving prediction accuracy on clean datasets. Further, in experiments attacking every class in CIFAR-10 and Tiny-ImageNet, given our restriction of no access to clean labels from the training set, our approach outperforms BadNet-c and Blend-c. We achieved the highest ASR on attacking all classes, where BadNet-c and Blend-c did not surpass a 10% ASR. Additionally, our performance exceeded that of HTBA, as depicted in Figure 3.

Trigger Evaluation. We conducted trigger evaluations on the CIFAR-10 and Tiny-ImageNet datasets. A clean ResNet network was trained, achieving test accuracies of 95.4% on CIFAR-10 and 69.3% on Tiny-ImageNet. We then applied various triggers to the entire training set and monitored their impact on CrossEntropyLoss, with results detailed in Table 4. Our findings indicate that triggers from BadNets and Blend were less effective in modifying image features, posing challenges for neural network learning. In contrast, DFB-generated triggers, optimized using the POOD dataset, significantly obscured key features, leading to a marked increase in CrossEntropyLoss. This effectively validates the approach outlined in our proposed formula 1.

references:
General Setup. The server system we used is Ubuntu 20.04, and it is equipped with two RTX 3090 GPUs as the hardware platform for conducting and evaluating experiments. In most experiments, we utilized the widely-adopted ResNet-18 architecture He et al. (2016) for the target model. For the encoder, the U-Net architecture Ronneberger et al. (2015) was chosen, while ResNet-18 was used for the decoder‚Äôs structure. To minimize the impact of network architecture on the outcomes, experiments were also conducted with different decoder architectures, such as VGG-16 Simonyan and Zisserman (2014) and VGG-19. Typically, the maximum poisoning ratio was set to 0.05%. The l‚àûsubscriptùëôl_{\infty}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm bound for trigger generation was established at 8/255, and the poisoning level at 16/255, in line with standard practices in existing studies Turner et al. (2019); Saha et al. (2020).


Datasets Setup. Our attack was evaluated on three datasets: CIFAR-10 Krizhevsky et al. (2009), Tiny-ImageNet Le and Yang (2015), and TSRD Dewi et al. (2020). Due to limitations in accessing training data, we selected POOD datasets corresponding to each victim model‚Äôs dataset, specifically Tiny-ImageNet, CIFAR-10, and GTSRB Stallkamp et al. (2011), ensuring no class overlap between the training and POOD datasets. Detailed information regarding the datasets used, the attack datasets, and the hyperparameters for each training pipeline is provided in Table 3.


Attack Setup. We evaluated two variants of DFB (fixed trigger and encoder trigger) against existing clean-label attacks, namely HTBA and LC, implementing these methods as described in their respective original papers. Note that this is an unfair comparison, as they can access the training set. Additionally, we modified two standard tainted-label attacks, BadNets and Blend (referred to as BadNets-c and Blend-c, respectively), by contaminating only the target category while preserving its original label, thus adapting them for a clean-label context. This is fair, as it is under the same conditions without access to the training set. Furthermore, we conducted dirty-label attacks using BadNets and Blend, denoted as BadNets-d and Blend-d, for comparative analysis with our approach. It should be noted, however, that comparing dirty-label attacks with clean-label methods is not entirely fair, as dirty-label attacks are more easily detectable by data validators.

Attack Effectiveness. Our comparative results with other attack methods are shown in Table 2. On CIFAR-10, Tiny-ImageNet, and TSRD datasets, with poisoning rates of 0.1%, 0.025%, and 0.4% respectively, DFB exhibits superior performance even under challenging conditions (i.e., without access to any training dataset). Utilizing fixed triggers from the POOD dataset, devoid of target-class features, and dynamically adjusting encoder triggers based on the training set, DFB achieves faster model injection. This results in a higher attack success rate (ASR) compared to LC and HTBA. In contrast to fair attacks like BadNets and Blend, our method shows higher success rates while preserving prediction accuracy on clean datasets. Further, in experiments attacking every class in CIFAR-10 and Tiny-ImageNet, given our restriction of no access to clean labels from the training set, our approach outperforms BadNet-c and Blend-c. We achieved the highest ASR on attacking all classes, where BadNet-c and Blend-c did not surpass a 10% ASR. Additionally, our performance exceeded that of HTBA, as depicted in Figure 3.

Trigger Evaluation. We conducted trigger evaluations on the CIFAR-10 and Tiny-ImageNet datasets. A clean ResNet network was trained, achieving test accuracies of 95.4% on CIFAR-10 and 69.3% on Tiny-ImageNet. We then applied various triggers to the entire training set and monitored their impact on CrossEntropyLoss, with results detailed in Table 4. Our findings indicate that triggers from BadNets and Blend were less effective in modifying image features, posing challenges for neural network learning. In contrast, DFB-generated triggers, optimized using the POOD dataset, significantly obscured key features, leading to a marked increase in CrossEntropyLoss. This effectively validates the approach outlined in our proposed formula 1.
